Posts.Content: Yes, Dave, My Uro says that after my RALP, if I have a detectable PSA, taken at 6 wks., he will recommend Adjuvant Radiation. So, this appears to be a typical strategy!

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 I'm not as knowledgeable as those who have been dealing with this for years, but I had a similar genetic test done called OncotypeDx GPS. In my case the blind biopsy showed I had Gleason 6, so the additional test was being done to evaluate whether active surveillance might be appropriate. I don't understand the logic in your case of the additional lab test (other than perhaps a confirmation of the biopsy). You should be relieved that the bone scan was negative. Maybe I missed it, but was a 3T MRI ordered? I would think that would be more helpful in determining a course of action than the genetic test. In any event, I wish you the best! Consult1, no just the NUC Whole Body Scan & CT Urogram were ordered and then the Prolaris. Good question to pose in my consult. Perhaps it is to determine how quickly to act and the method. Have not discussed any strategy yet. Thanks for the input!

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: I am 69 and been lurking for about a month, since my diagnosis, and now with just about all of the facts, thought I would get the advice of you brave and knowledgeable individuals, regarding my next step! I would like to think my PSA of 51.2, was at least a little high, due to having ejaculated, jogged a mile, lifted heavy weights and mowed for an hour on my John Deere, within 24 to 48 hours before the test. Like others have expressed, it is not common knowledge what not to do before having a PSA test done. I am waiting on the Prolaris test (maybe next week) to help determine how aggressive it is and then a consult on 9/11/17 (crazy date, huh). Scans were CLEAR. Seeking anyone's thoughts on possible course of action. I am leaning towards robotic, radical surgery, foregoing possible side effects over more likelihood of possible permanent cure, if that is even possible? Let me know if you need more info. from the biopsy? Oh by the way, it has a UroScore Report in it, which I haven't been able to find much info. on, on the NET. Thoughts from you courageous, knowledgeable and VERY wise survivors, would really be appreciated.

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Thanks, Southsider and Highlander, for the info. I am not that familiar with the Partin tables. I didn't add any detail on the CT Urogram Scan, other than it was clear. How accurate is it, because it provides the following: The lung bases and lower mediastinal structures appear to be unremarkable. The visualized liver demonstrates no discrete mass or biliary dilatation. The spleen appears unremarkable. Gallbladder is contracted with gallstones noted. The pancreas and adrenal glands appear to be unremarkable. Kidneys and collecting system demonstrates no signs of urinary calculi. Contrast images demonstrate no sign of suspicious mass within the kidneys. No hydronephrosis noted. No filling defects are seen. The bladder appears to be unremarkable. Prostatic enlargement noted. No abscess or free air. No significant adenopathy. Diverticulosis seen involving the descending and sigmoid colon. Of course, if surgery is performed, metastasis will be more obvious, around the Prostate, I assume? Thanks, so much for your input!

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MRJ Mike, you'll need to train your bladder to wait just a bit longer than it wants to. Instead of getting up and going when you first feel the urge, you'll need to wait just a little, then go. Mike, 1st few days off the cath, I had a similar problem of almost constant dribbling, when standing up. One online source recommended sitting on the toilet every 2 hrs. the first day and then lengthen the time between each day until you have some control. Can you stop your flow midstream? This is a good exercise, too. Some claim lots of walking helps gain control, also. Unfortunately, my cath was in for 3 weeks so my bladder really lost some muscle. So, I am trying to "pump it back up". Doc. said I would have difficulty figuring out when to go and would have to go more often for the first week. So, it can be different for everyone but the goal is to just see improvement over time and most likely nothing is wrong. Hang in there!

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: I am 69 and been lurking for about a month, since my diagnosis, and now with just about all of the facts, thought I would get the advice of you brave and knowledgeable individuals, regarding my next step! I would like to think my PSA of 51.2, was at least a little high, due to having ejaculated, jogged a mile, lifted heavy weights and mowed for an hour on my John Deere, within 24 to 48 hours before the test. Like others have expressed, it is not common knowledge what not to do before having a PSA test done. I am waiting on the Prolaris test (maybe next week) to help determine how aggressive it is and then a consult on 9/11/17 (crazy date, huh). Scans were CLEAR. Seeking anyone's thoughts on possible course of action. I am leaning towards robotic, radical surgery, foregoing possible side effects over more likelihood of possible permanent cure, if that is even possible? Let me know if you need more info. from the biopsy? Oh by the way, it has a UroScore Report in it, which I haven't been able to find much info. on, on the NET. Thoughts from you courageous, knowledgeable and VERY wise survivors, would really be appreciated.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 I'm not as knowledgeable as those who have been dealing with this for years, but I had a similar genetic test done called OncotypeDx GPS. In my case the blind biopsy showed I had Gleason 6, so the additional test was being done to evaluate whether active surveillance might be appropriate. I don't understand the logic in your case of the additional lab test (other than perhaps a confirmation of the biopsy). You should be relieved that the bone scan was negative. Maybe I missed it, but was a 3T MRI ordered? I would think that would be more helpful in determining a course of action than the genetic test. In any event, I wish you the best! Consult1, no just the NUC Whole Body Scan & CT Urogram were ordered and then the Prolaris. Good question to pose in my consult. Perhaps it is to determine how quickly to act and the method. Have not discussed any strategy yet. Thanks for the input!

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 I'm not as knowledgeable as those who have been dealing with this for years, but I had a similar genetic test done called OncotypeDx GPS. In my case the blind biopsy showed I had Gleason 6, so the additional test was being done to evaluate whether active surveillance might be appropriate. I don't understand the logic in your case of the additional lab test (other than perhaps a confirmation of the biopsy). You should be relieved that the bone scan was negative. Maybe I missed it, but was a 3T MRI ordered? I would think that would be more helpful in determining a course of action than the genetic test. In any event, I wish you the best! Consult1, no just the NUC Whole Body Scan & CT Urogram were ordered and then the Prolaris. Good question to pose in my consult. Perhaps it is to determine how quickly to act and the method. Have not discussed any strategy yet. Thanks for the input!

Posts.Content: Thanks, Southsider and Highlander, for the info. I am not that familiar with the Partin tables. I didn't add any detail on the CT Urogram Scan, other than it was clear. How accurate is it, because it provides the following: The lung bases and lower mediastinal structures appear to be unremarkable. The visualized liver demonstrates no discrete mass or biliary dilatation. The spleen appears unremarkable. Gallbladder is contracted with gallstones noted. The pancreas and adrenal glands appear to be unremarkable. Kidneys and collecting system demonstrates no signs of urinary calculi. Contrast images demonstrate no sign of suspicious mass within the kidneys. No hydronephrosis noted. No filling defects are seen. The bladder appears to be unremarkable. Prostatic enlargement noted. No abscess or free air. No significant adenopathy. Diverticulosis seen involving the descending and sigmoid colon. Of course, if surgery is performed, metastasis will be more obvious, around the Prostate, I assume? Thanks, so much for your input!

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: I am 69 and been lurking for about a month, since my diagnosis, and now with just about all of the facts, thought I would get the advice of you brave and knowledgeable individuals, regarding my next step! I would like to think my PSA of 51.2, was at least a little high, due to having ejaculated, jogged a mile, lifted heavy weights and mowed for an hour on my John Deere, within 24 to 48 hours before the test. Like others have expressed, it is not common knowledge what not to do before having a PSA test done. I am waiting on the Prolaris test (maybe next week) to help determine how aggressive it is and then a consult on 9/11/17 (crazy date, huh). Scans were CLEAR. Seeking anyone's thoughts on possible course of action. I am leaning towards robotic, radical surgery, foregoing possible side effects over more likelihood of possible permanent cure, if that is even possible? Let me know if you need more info. from the biopsy? Oh by the way, it has a UroScore Report in it, which I haven't been able to find much info. on, on the NET. Thoughts from you courageous, knowledgeable and VERY wise survivors, would really be appreciated.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 I'm not as knowledgeable as those who have been dealing with this for years, but I had a similar genetic test done called OncotypeDx GPS. In my case the blind biopsy showed I had Gleason 6, so the additional test was being done to evaluate whether active surveillance might be appropriate. I don't understand the logic in your case of the additional lab test (other than perhaps a confirmation of the biopsy). You should be relieved that the bone scan was negative. Maybe I missed it, but was a 3T MRI ordered? I would think that would be more helpful in determining a course of action than the genetic test. In any event, I wish you the best! Consult1, no just the NUC Whole Body Scan & CT Urogram were ordered and then the Prolaris. Good question to pose in my consult. Perhaps it is to determine how quickly to act and the method. Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Thanks, Southsider and Highlander, for the info. I am not that familiar with the Partin tables. I didn't add any detail on the CT Urogram Scan, other than it was clear. How accurate is it, because it provides the following: The lung bases and lower mediastinal structures appear to be unremarkable. The visualized liver demonstrates no discrete mass or biliary dilatation. The spleen appears unremarkable. Gallbladder is contracted with gallstones noted. The pancreas and adrenal glands appear to be unremarkable. Kidneys and collecting system demonstrates no signs of urinary calculi. Contrast images demonstrate no sign of suspicious mass within the kidneys. No hydronephrosis noted. No filling defects are seen. The bladder appears to be unremarkable. Prostatic enlargement noted. No abscess or free air. No significant adenopathy. Diverticulosis seen involving the descending and sigmoid colon. Of course, if surgery is performed, metastasis will be more obvious, around the Prostate, I assume? Thanks, so much for your input!

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: I am 69 and been lurking for about a month, since my diagnosis, and now with just about all of the facts, thought I would get the advice of you brave and knowledgeable individuals, regarding my next step! I would like to think my PSA of 51.2, was at least a little high, due to having ejaculated, jogged a mile, lifted heavy weights and mowed for an hour on my John Deere, within 24 to 48 hours before the test. Like others have expressed, it is not common knowledge what not to do before having a PSA test done. I am waiting on the Prolaris test (maybe next week) to help determine how aggressive it is and then a consult on 9/11/17 (crazy date, huh). Scans were CLEAR. Seeking anyone's thoughts on possible course of action. I am leaning towards robotic, radical surgery, foregoing possible side effects over more likelihood of possible permanent cure, if that is even possible? Let me know if you need more info. from the biopsy? Oh by the way, it has a UroScore Report in it, which I haven't been able to find much info. on, on the NET. Thoughts from you courageous, knowledgeable and VERY wise survivors, would really be appreciated.

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MRJ Mike, you'll need to train your bladder to wait just a bit longer than it wants to. Instead of getting up and going when you first feel the urge, you'll need to wait just a little, then go. Mike, 1st few days off the cath, I had a similar problem of almost constant dribbling, when standing up. One online source recommended sitting on the toilet every 2 hrs. the first day and then lengthen the time between each day until you have some control. Can you stop your flow midstream? This is a good exercise, too. Some claim lots of walking helps gain control, also. Unfortunately, my cath was in for 3 weeks so my bladder really lost some muscle. So, I am trying to "pump it back up". Doc. said I would have difficulty figuring out when to go and would have to go more often for the first week. So, it can be different for everyone but the goal is to just see improvement over time and most likely nothing is wrong. Hang in there!

Posts.Title: Bladder Urgency and Frequency Post Surgery

Posts.Content: TPJ, I am 5 days ahead of you. Going under the "knife" (RALP) Wednesday! Going for pre-surgery checkup, today, due to mix up in getting the order in! We are the same age, so will have to compare our outcomes! Looking forward to it; no more than getting your teeth cleaned - oh no that was the biopsy! As others have said, being in good physical shape, should help! So, we will see? My doc wants me to use a special soap, morning of the surgery, CHG, but having trouble finding it and based on discussions on the forum, seems not commonly used? So, I may forgo it? Start starving myself and cleansing my colon, tomorrow. Looking less toward that than the actual surgery! Easy to say on this side of it! I am just ready to get it out of me and move on. The guys, on this forum, have been an invaluable resource and are really helping me relax, as much as one can be expected, all things considered. So, I hope to be able to give you some positive feedback in a few days? Just hang in there and best of luck! However, sometimes we make our own luck and it sounds like you have done all you can to get ready!

Posts.Title: Best Exercise for Aging Muscles

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi You mention another Lupron shot. Are you staying on Casodex for the duration of your Lupron therapy? I ask because I’m on the same 2ADT regime an am flummoxed about continuing the Casodex. Thanks, and keep those 00’s coming! It is interesting that you bring this up, garyi, because my wife and I have the same question and will confront our new Medical Oncologist (MO), next week, when getting the Lupron injection. My RALP surgeon was the one to start me on Lupron/Casodex, possibly for the alleged "flare" that can occur and my Radiation Oncologist (RO) questioned whether I should stay on it but deferred to the MO. Have you read anything challenging the duo, because I am definitely interested? So, otherwise, I will report back, next week.

Posts.Title: First PSA, Post RALP & RT & 6 Months ADT = <0.10.

Posts.Content: Don't know how significant this is, while under the spell of Lupron/Casodex. Been six months since RALP and ADT and 6 weeks post RT. My T level went up 4 units to 24 within 4-1/2 months. Don't know if this is significant or due to being only 1 week from my next 6 month Lupron injection. It has been actually longer than 6 months, since my first injection, by 1 week? So, am I in the "zero club" or is it too soon to know?

Posts.Title: First PSA, Post RALP & RT & 6 Months ADT = <0.10.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lastchance Physical therapist told me last week to do kegels standing. She assured me that when I would leak. Surgery was yesterday 12/4/2017 and back home on 12/5/2017. Trying to get accustomed to the Cath. Been a hell of a ride so far. Wow, lastchance, congratulations! It probably seems surreal, at this point, to have it done? Keep from getting constipated, especially while the cath is in or you will push out a lot of blood and urine around the cath while straining. Swelling of the scrotum (and color) might be a bid deal but will go down in a week or two? Makes it more difficult to walk/waddle. Makes it harder to bend over, tie your shoes, take a shower, etc. Keep us informed of your journey!

Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: tpj, My first night without Foley, I slept almost 5 hours and realized I better empty the bladder but not so much due to a sensation. Peed like a 17 yr. old! Went back to sleep for 3 more hours and got up and emptied again before staying up. So, night time completely dry but like you guys, standing results in dribbles. Sitting is better. I can stop flow midstream so there is still some muscle control in the lazy bladder. One day at a time.

Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I had bladder spasm near the end of my catheter period. Very, very, very painful. Uncontrollable. Just had to beathe through them and wait them out. Similar to birth contractions, but probably not as large. I found pushing some with them relieved some of the discomfort. Resisting them and trying to make them stop only made it worse. When I asked the doctor he said it was a sign of healing. I assumed attempt by the bladder to reject the catheter. Mine was in for longer than normal. They continued mildly after removal of the catheter whenever I urinated and ended within a few days. It is a muscle cramp. If you had an enlarged prostate and reduced stream your bladder (a muscle) has gotten muscled up forcing urine through the restricted urethra. When it cramps you will feel it. Try some electrolytes. Wow, Another, I will have my cath in 13 days, assuming the leak heals? Hope I don't share your problem. My Prostate ended up being 70 gm. (2x what biopsy showed), hopefully not too muscular. I don't remember your signature, did you have RT in the St. Louis area. Now that I know I will have to, I am researching alternatives. Thanks!

Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: tpjames, Finally got my Foley out today (3 wks.) and the Doc. said I would have difficulty feeling when to go and would have to go more frequently for several days because, my formerly muscular bladder, is now not so muscular. An online article said to just go sit on the toilet every 2 hours and every day try to lengthen the time between toilet visits.

Posts.Title: Those Slumbering Nerves

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Bernard/ John. Sorry to be the bearer of bad news. RP, SRT, and HT can spell the end of natural erections. Those 3 things are very tough to overcome. Im in that situation now, and my uro has told me Im not dead yet. I dont believe him. Im planning on a implant. Just the way it is. Good luck, MM Well, MM, I can't say I will miss it that much. The ole saying that males think about sex every 7 second, although a misnomer probably, it is amazing how much time is wasted in the en devour. The Lupron has started to make my wife look less sexy, already and she doesn't care. At her age, it is definitely not a big deal. And has been said many times, on this forum, dead men can't get erections! For the younger guys it's more important, however.

Posts.Title: Those Slumbering Nerves

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Charlies wife My husband had robotic prostatectomy on Nov 7, 2017. The cancer had went outside of the prostate so the Seminole Vesicle was removed along with the lymph nodes. Pathology shows the left vesicle was cancerous as well as 1 lymph node out of 3 and 32% of the prostate. Path also scored him as a Gleason 9. Recovery is going pretty good after 3 days of fighting the results of the CO2. He biggest problem is his penis and scrotum are so swollen and painful. Does anyone know how long this will last. Charlie's wife, how is it going with your hubby. My scrotum is finally close to normal (day 14) and it makes a big difference in wanting to do things. You don't have to waddle when you walk. Hopefully, he is showing some improvement and, unlike me, his catheter will come out at a more normal time, which will also make a great difference? Keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Swollen Penis and scrotum

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Use undergarments that are a snug stretch fit. 100% synthetic, no cotton. They will provide support. He should be seeing it go down. It will take a while, but it should not be worsening after this much time (except for color). Color can be scary as it turns black (mostly) and blue. Good point, Another! I am wearing jockies vs. boxers, which work pretty well. Recline with a rolled up towel or thick pair of socks (I got from the hospital) underneath them to further elevate them.

Posts.Title: Swollen Penis and scrotum

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Charlie’s wife My husband had robotic prostatectomy on Nov 7, 2017. The cancer had went outside of the prostate so the Seminole Vesicle was removed along with the lymph nodes. Pathology shows the left vesicle was cancerous as well as 1 lymph node out of 3 and 32% of the prostate. Path also scored him as a Gleason 9. Recovery is going pretty good after 3 days of fighting the results of the CO2. He biggest problem is his penis and scrotum are so swollen and painful. Does anyone know how long this will last. CW, yes it is very common, as I have read on another forum. Mine became swollen after a few days and turned black and blue. My Doc. told me to elevate them. Still try to walk but it may be more of a waddle. I put an ice pack on them sometimes and that reduced the swelling but it will come back until they have healed. They returned to normal color after about a week and still are not normal at day 12, but getting close. My left side still has a little pain and I just take tylenol but he may need something more. Check with the Doc. Bottom line it is just part of the surgical side effects and very common and some have it worse than others and some not at all. I also sent you a private message.

Posts.Title: Swollen Penis and scrotum

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Charlie’s wife John 4803, hubby doing good. It was 3 weeks this past Tuesday since his surgery. He had his catheter removed a week after the surgery. He still has some swelling in the abdomen but it has went down considerably. His scrotum and penis are still swollen. They both go down some at night but go back up after he gets up. He reclines most of the time which helps some but according to him not enough! He did finally put some jeans on this week which he said did help as far as support but he still is in the waddling state when he walks. He has been outside walking more this week which I think helped some. After reading about everyone else having the same problems it helps relieve the anxiety which also helps. He said it it wasn’t for the boys being three times their size he would be in great shape considering. He is also a pT3b, GS 9 with one positive lymph node. Incontinence is not bad. Dry at night and mostly during the day except when getting up, sneezing etc. Has already switched from wearing the guard pads to the lighter pad which I feel is pretty good. Go back for his first PSA and follow up since surgery on 1-3-18. Hoping for a good read but prepared for probable radiation treatments. How long did you have to have the catheter. How are you doing with treatments? If you look at my signature, we are nearly the same. I had 3/7 lymph node, seminal vesicles + and + margin between bladder neck and prostate. Periprostatic tissue = -. My Doc. feels he got everything but you never know about the microscopic cells. He immediately put me on Lupron and Casodex to stop any growth for 3-6 months so my body could heal before adjuvant radiation. I'm going back at week 3 to get the catheter removed, maybe? Where he sewed the ureter to the bladder neck the neck was inflamed by being pushed on by prostate and is healing slowly. He also did a sample there, too. Nothing in the bladder fortunately. Sounds like big decisions ahead? Keep us informed.

Posts.Title: Swollen Penis and scrotum

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Charlie’s wife John 4803, hubby doing good. It was 3 weeks this past Tuesday since his surgery. He had his catheter removed a week after the surgery. He still has some swelling in the abdomen but it has went down considerably. His scrotum and penis are still swollen. They both go down some at night but go back up after he gets up. He reclines most of the time which helps some but according to him not enough! He did finally put some jeans on this week which he said did help as far as support but he still is in the waddling state when he walks. He has been outside walking more this week which I think helped some. After reading about everyone else having the same problems it helps relieve the anxiety which also helps. He said it it wasn’t for the boys being three times their size he would be in great shape considering. He is also a pT3b, GS 9 with one positive lymph node. Incontinence is not bad. Dry at night and mostly during the day except when getting up, sneezing etc. Has already switched from wearing the guard pads to the lighter pad which I feel is pretty good. Go back for his first PSA and follow up since surgery on 1-3-18. Hoping for a good read but prepared for probable radiation treatments. How long did you have to have the catheter. How are you doing with treatments? If you look at my signature, we are nearly the same. I had 3/7 lymph node, seminal vesicles + and + margin between bladder neck and prostate. Periprostatic tissue = -. My Doc. feels he got everything but you never know about the microscopic cells. He immediately put me on Lupron and Casodex to stop any growth for 3-6 months so my body could heal before adjuvant radiation. I'm going back at week 3 to get the catheter removed, maybe? Where he sewed the ureter to the bladder neck the neck was inflamed by being pushed on by prostate and is healing slowly. He also did a sample there, too. Nothing in the bladder fortunately. Sounds like big decisions ahead? Keep us informed.

Posts.Title: Swollen Penis and scrotum

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tpjames 1st PSA since surgery Nov 21, reported < 0.1 which was stated as undetectable . Will be tested every 3 months for 2 years, then every 6 months for 2 years. Then, if all is well, once a year. I was told that anything reported .2 or above may require attention. We talked about many things, incontinence being one. I have never had an issue of WET at night and the stress incontinence during the day is less and less each week. Several weeks back I stopped using any pads at night and this week I have started with NO pads during the day. A very minimal drop now and then. I do understand that if I am doing any assertive work it would be good to use a thin pad. Regarding ED, still not woke up but sensations are there , something is going on, I can feel it waking up. I am now cleared to use 100 MG of Viagra (Sildenafil) , lets see what happens. Even though I was expecting to be a member of Club Zero, it is still a relief to hear the words and learn the results. Been a crazy last 6 months thats for sure. best to all t Fantastic news, tpj!!!!!!!! I stopped using pads at about 10 weeks. Reread Dr. Catalona on what the bladder has to go through during surgery to help perspective: http://www.drcatalona.com/quest/quest_spring03_2.htm

Posts.Title: Sor Far, So Good

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BAB Keep good spirits! I started a clinical trial (post RALP) at Johns Hopkins for guys with metastatic PCa. The regiment started off with 4 sessions of Docetaxel (each session separated by 3 weeks). Also began Lupron on same day as starting chemo. My major side effect from the chemo was tiredness -- which began on day 5 after chemo and lasted about 4 days. My hair thinned but I did NOT lose it. After completing chemo I had 69 Gray of radiation. PSA has been tested each quarter after surgery and has stayed at .01. Have been reading a LOT of research (as most of us do!), and it seems as if administering docetaxel for guys like us has become popular. My doc (Dr. Pienta) feels that administering the chemo early treats some of the systemic cells (I had two lymph nodes that tested positive.) Not enjoying the ADT, but you do what you gotta do! BAB, As you can see from my signature, I too, had 4+5 and + bladder margin, and 3 of 7 lymph nodes +, plus, but also + sv's and vas deferens. So far, I have had RALP, starting Lupron & Cassodex, following final path. After 3 months I am about to start RT, for 8 wks. to Pelvic bed and Pelvic and Periaortic Lymph Nodes. My RO, yesterday, recommended I do Chemo 2 weeks following RT. This surprised me because I had the advanced Axumin PET scan, showing no obvious mets. He is convinced, that with a 4+5 most likely I have microscopic mets beyond the Pelvic area and Chemo, combined with ADT is the new way to go. So, I meet with the MO on the 2/20/18 to discuss. Definitely not looking forward to Chemo. I noticed you had genetic testing done. Was that a factor in going with Chemo?

Posts.Content: Yes, the MRI is not reliable for specifics. Mine showed my SV's "symmetrical" and both had cancer. It was not clear that the cancer had invaded the bladder neck either, making my GS go from 4+4 to 4+9. The final path, post RALP, revealed it all, one of the advantages of surgery but you have to look at all of the options, before deciding.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi John...how is that doubleheader ADT dose of Lupron and Casodex treating you? I ask since the same may be in my near future. Thanks.... Gary, so far maybe a little constipation only. They can either constipate or loosen you up? No Lupron brain so far. My wife claims I have had that problem for years? I will keep you posted on my thread: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...mp-new-to-site

Posts.Title: After davinci RP for prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by renfro Hello everyone, Found this forum about a week ago. Great info. I haven't done the forum posting thing much in the past however, I thought I would give it go today. As the title says I have my Da Vinci surgery scheduled for tomorrow. A little anxious, but feeling ok. The surgeon doing the procedure is very highly rated and considered one of the best in the area, if not the country. It's being done at one of the top university medical centers in the country. They've been excellent in preparing me for the process and I feel fortunate that I'm able to have my surgery done there. I've been reading about post surgery experiences on this forum and it's been very helpful in preparing for what and what not to expect. Between this forum and what the hospital staff is sure to tell me before my release, I should be in pretty good shape making it through a good recovery. Thank you. Welcome, renfo! I am 4 wks. post op and getting closer to normal every day. I kept making sure the ice pack on my abdomen stayed cold, my only night in the hospital, to relieve the discomfort and swelling. Don't plan to sleep much, there will be time for that. Don't forget the stool softeners because the bladder is sensitive to pushing with foley in it. Tomorrow evening, no matter how you feel, will be a great relief, knowing that it is over! Best of luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Biopsy results back - Feel like squirrel crossing busy street

Posts.Content: pajaroja, As others have pointed out, a genetic test might help, in your decision? If you look at my signature, you will see I have 4, GS 8's but per the biopsies and MRI, it seems to be organ confined. I had the genetic test, Prolaris, done and it shows metastasis risk (10 yr.) of 29.6% and Mortality Risk (10 yr.) of 23.5%. So, I don't think I should postpone anything. I have researched a lot, read lots of forum posts and want to just get rid of it. My Biopsy Uro recommended any of 3 options, RALP, External Beam Radiation and Brachytherapy, but said for himself, he would choose Radiation. With surgery, I can still choose Radiation later but, from my understanding, it is harder to do Radiation first and surgery later, if necessary. Others may know better about this? My RALP, scheduled for 11/15/17, will be performed by one of the top surgeons, in the St. Louis area, who has completed 600. I understand, the skill of the surgeon is critical in side effect outcome, but you shouldn't expect better continence or ED, post surgery than pre-surgery, unless maybe your prostrate was so big it was restricting flow, etc. As others have said, you still have time to research more. Also, provide more information, so forum members, who have probably forgotten more about this scourge than we will ever know, and can be an invaluable resource!

Posts.Content: pajaroja, As others have pointed out, a genetic test might help, in your decision? If you look at my signature, you will see I have 4, GS 8's but per the biopsies and MRI, it seems to be organ confined. I had the genetic test, Prolaris, done and it shows metastasis risk (10 yr.) of 29.6% and Mortality Risk (10 yr.) of 23.5%. So, I don't think I should postpone anything. I have researched a lot, read lots of forum posts and want to just get rid of it. My Biopsy Uro recommended any of 3 options, RALP, External Beam Radiation and Brachytherapy, but said for himself, he would choose Radiation. With surgery, I can still choose Radiation later but, from my understanding, it is harder to do Radiation first and surgery later, if necessary. Others may know better about this? My RALP, scheduled for 11/15/17, will be performed by one of the top surgeons, in the St. Louis area, who has completed 600. I understand, the skill of the surgeon is critical in side effect outcome, but you shouldn't expect better continence or ED, post surgery than pre-surgery, unless maybe your prostrate was so big it was restricting flow, etc. As others have said, you still have time to research more. Also, provide more information, so forum members, who have probably forgotten more about this scourge than we will ever know, and can be an invaluable resource!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gorhad They say "Patience is a virtue"... I'm sorry but my impatience has a leading edge. I feel I've recovered quite quickly in every way other than ED. I was having Nocturnal Erections and thought YEEEESS he's coming back to life sadly they diminished quickly. Viagara, Cialis they really haven't done anything other than give me a thumping headache or heartburn Without being too crude...There's only so many things you can can perform sexually without the aid of an erection before it becomes boring or "im too tired tonight babe". I appreciate its a healing process and im probably trying to run before i can walk but it is becoming an ongoing concern in my mind daily Thanks PS got my first major review post op on Friday with PSA test results.. I'm going to mention it to the doc Gorhad, excuse my Lupron brain (boy I use that excuse more and more) but I don't see when you had RALP or RT or whatever you had and a timeline as to where you are now, on your signature?

Posts.Title: RALP tommorow. Oh boy!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by renfro Hello everyone, Found this forum about a week ago. Great info. I haven't done the forum posting thing much in the past however, I thought I would give it go today. As the title says I have my Da Vinci surgery scheduled for tomorrow. A little anxious, but feeling ok. The surgeon doing the procedure is very highly rated and considered one of the best in the area, if not the country. It's being done at one of the top university medical centers in the country. They've been excellent in preparing me for the process and I feel fortunate that I'm able to have my surgery done there. I've been reading about post surgery experiences on this forum and it's been very helpful in preparing for what and what not to expect. Between this forum and what the hospital staff is sure to tell me before my release, I should be in pretty good shape making it through a good recovery. Thank you. Welcome, renfo! I am 4 wks. post op and getting closer to normal every day. I kept making sure the ice pack on my abdomen stayed cold, my only night in the hospital, to relieve the discomfort and swelling. Don't plan to sleep much, there will be time for that. Don't forget the stool softeners because the bladder is sensitive to pushing with foley in it. Tomorrow evening, no matter how you feel, will be a great relief, knowing that it is over! Best of luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Biopsy results back - Feel like squirrel crossing busy street

Posts.Content: My Doc. had me use Neosporin, 2 to 4 times per day. Because I had positive margins on the bladder neck and the prostate, it was critical that the connection (anastomosis) healed so he had it pressure tested at twice the pressure as during surgery. It took 3 weeks for it to fully heal. In hind site, however, I am glad he didn't rush it because the connection stayed fully open and my flow has continued to be like a 17 year old, even after 37 doses of radiation. I know guys, whose Doc's rushed it and didn't properly heal and have to have it "reamed out" later. You can't tell this just by urine color, either. Mine had no blood it it on day 2. If your fiance's surgery was not complicated, it probably won't be an issue. As previously stated, if he is having bladder spasms, there are medications for that. As a result, when he is having a bowel movement, urine comes out around the catheter. This is not unusual but uncomfortable. As we all agree, in not too long of a time, it will be a distant memory!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gorhad They say "Patience is a virtue"... I'm sorry but my impatience has a leading edge. I feel I've recovered quite quickly in every way other than ED. I was having Nocturnal Erections and thought YEEEESS he's coming back to life sadly they diminished quickly. Viagara, Cialis they really haven't done anything other than give me a thumping headache or heartburn Without being too crude...There's only so many things you can can perform sexually without the aid of an erection before it becomes boring or "im too tired tonight babe". I appreciate its a healing process and im probably trying to run before i can walk but it is becoming an ongoing concern in my mind daily Thanks PS got my first major review post op on Friday with PSA test results.. I'm going to mention it to the doc Gorhad, excuse my Lupron brain (boy I use that excuse more and more) but I don't see when you had RALP or RT or whatever you had and a timeline as to where you are now, on your signature?

Posts.Title: One Day Post-op

Posts.Content: Like both you tp and Gerd I have to leave Foley in longer, at least 13 days. Like you tp my connection was tricky due to my dam prostate pushing up on the bladder neck and irritating it. First cystogram showed a leak and have to get another one next Tues. before I lose Foley. Put the leg catheter on when you can and you almost feel normal. My scrotum wants to swell, if I walk too much, and have to elevate them which does not work with the leg bag as well. You are over the hump and it is all down hill from here! Welcome to the other side!

Posts.Title: 3rd morning post RALP surgery

Posts.Content: jeff, Tomorrow will be 6 wks. after my RALP and I can start jogging and lifting weights again and I am ready. Still dribbling a little at times but that gets better everyday. The surgery for you will seem like it takes a second or two, whereas, your wife will suffer the agony of the actual time spent. Based on your GS I would think your surgery would pretty short in length. And if it is all confined he won't have to do a lot of extra exploratory surgery, resulting in less swelling, healing, etc. So, relax and before you know it will be over. I am already starting to forget some of the details and at times it seems like it was a dream. Of course, then I look in the mirror and see the 6 small scars and realize it was not. Best of luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas, RALP now 4 days away

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I believe so. I see it referred to as the prostate fossa, or bed: the depression or area where the prostate was. Of course if other precise areas are revealed on imaging, those can be targeted too, in theory. The prostate fossa may in fact have residual prostate tissue missed in the RP and the areas at positive margins with other structures may be targeted. This is just what I've surmised from reading. Other brothers who have gotten SRT can be more precise. From what I have read, you can never be sure about Lymph Nodes (LN), unless they are all sampled, and a sample is just that? And any positive margins are red flags for the bed, although, in my case the sampling of the Periprostatic tissue showed no cancer. But my RO wants to be aggressive, for reasons Djintonic points out, plus, the fact that 3 of 7 LN's were positive and wants to go higher than normal, to the periaortic LN's, to be sure everything is hit. So, one has to weigh aggressiveness and possible toxic affects with missing the millions of cancer cells that can be in one cubic millimeter of space, that won't necessarily show up on even the Axumin PET scan, and become harder to kill once they mutate and are attempted to fry later! With today's advanced RT equipment and, in my case, the proposed use of Cone-Beam CT, IMRT, and the aggressiveness of my cancer, I agree with my RO (who was once head of the MO RO Association & on the board of the US Association), to throw everything at it. Bottom line, however, for each of us, you have to decide, on your own with recommendations, of course, what procedure is best for you!

Posts.Title: Seminal vesicles spread

Posts.Content: Jeff, I don't see anything about lymph nodes. Were any examined? 3 of 7 of mine sampled were cancerous, thus, the RT, I start next month will also be aimed at the numerous nodes, in case something is lurking and not killed by the Lupron. The dosage is only 45 gys vs. 65 for the Prostate bed. Like several of us I am having the Trifecta to cover all of the bases. My RO is using cone beam ct imaging to even further narrow the field to better target exactly where the radiation is going. He claims he has seen a reduction of 5% in SE's with this approach, already. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Post Surgery report back tpjames

Posts.Content: Keep it up, nixter, and protect little foley and try to see him as a temporary friend! Consider staying on stool softeners because any straining may tend to cause bladder spasms and urine to come out around him! Hopefully, your scrotum won't balloon up, like mine did, but it is normal. It makes for waddling vs. walking for a while. Keep looking forward!

Posts.Title: One Day Post-op

Posts.Content: Like both you tp and Gerd I have to leave Foley in longer, at least 13 days. Like you tp my connection was tricky due to my dam prostate pushing up on the bladder neck and irritating it. First cystogram showed a leak and have to get another one next Tues. before I lose Foley. Put the leg catheter on when you can and you almost feel normal. My scrotum wants to swell, if I walk too much, and have to elevate them which does not work with the leg bag as well. You are over the hump and it is all down hill from here! Welcome to the other side!

Posts.Title: 4 weeks post RALP, 1st Dr follow up appt today

Posts.Content: Djintonic, So far, I have had RALP, starting Lupron & Cassodex, following final path. After 3 months I am about to start RT, for 8 wks. to Pelvic bed and Pelvic and Periaortic Lymph Nodes. My RO, yesterday, recommended I do Chemo 2 weeks following RT. This surprised me because I had the advanced Axumin PET scan, showing no obvious mets. He is convinced, that with a 4+5 most likely I have microscopic mets beyond the Pelvic area and Chemo, combined with ADT is the new way to go. So, I meet with the MO on the 2/20/18 to discuss. Definitely not looking forward to Chemo. He will probably propose 6 cycles of Docetaxel every 3 wks. approximately 2 weeks following RT. Heard anything about this? I think they are leaning toward the Stampede and CHAARTED studies recommending combining ADT and Chemo?

Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer (NEJM)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 John4803: Are they adding the Chemo because of the positive nodes? Standard of care for pT3bNO has been ( assuming they had surgery) ART/SRT, along with up to 2 years of ADT. I received this answer from 3 different doctors. I have also noticed that some RO/ MO are also throwing Zytiga in the mix with ADT. The studies to which you refer have been around since I started treatment...wondering what has changed. You are correct, G8-10 can be highly predictive of micro-mets. When I asked my uro if SRT/ADT could kill off stray cells, his answer was..."We think it can". But no conclusive evidence. Ask your RO the question as to why the standard of care may or may not have changed. Most of the pT3BNO on this forum have had the triple whammy of Surgery, SRT, ADT. Not many chemo additions. Good luck, MM MM, I will ask the MO, whom I first meet on 2/21, is this the new standard of care, and supported by the insurance companies. I suspect the insurance companies will rule?

Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer (NEJM)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by cvictim So I had surgery in 2011 then PSA rising to about 3.4 by 2014 Received Radiation at the prostate bed. since then PSA has risen at the same rate as it did after surgery. Supposedly the cancer is somewhere but where..? The PSA was lowered before the Radiation with hormone therapy drugs to about .12 1) HAving said that I received over 30 rounds of Radiation therapy directed at the prostate bed to no Avail..? 2) If the radiation did not kill the cancer this must mean that it spread beyond the prostate bed and it was not there after the surgery. I'm confused has anyone else run into this situation.? cvictim, I am not in your situation but my RO is trying to keep this from happening by not only zapping lymph nodes (I had 3/7 tested positive) in the pelvis region but he is going higher to the paraaortic region. So, did you have any lymph nodes tested? Your signature would be interesting to see?

Posts.Title: Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by cvictim "So, did you have any lymph nodes tested? " No, what kind of test is involved..? When I went for surgery he stated that the lymph nodes in that region were clear upon observation. Am I missing something that should of been tested prior to surgery and prior to having Radiation to the Prostate bed based on the likelihood of cancer cells been present in that area when in fact my PSA was rising at the same rate After Radiation. I now have serious continent problems and damage to the lower colon and rectal area. My bladder was checked not long ago, its negative. Usually the surgeon cuts into or removes some lymph nodes to verify there is no cancer in them. Maybe you can be sure by just looking but my surgeon actually sampled some for the Pathologist to exam? An Axumin Pet scan will show cancer tumors if they are large enough. Have you had any scans?

Posts.Title: Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: jeff, Tomorrow will be 6 wks. after my RALP and I can start jogging and lifting weights again and I am ready. Still dribbling a little at times but that gets better everyday. The surgery for you will seem like it takes a second or two, whereas, your wife will suffer the agony of the actual time spent. Based on your GS I would think your surgery would pretty short in length. And if it is all confined he won't have to do a lot of extra exploratory surgery, resulting in less swelling, healing, etc. So, relax and before you know it will be over. I am already starting to forget some of the details and at times it seems like it was a dream. Of course, then I look in the mirror and see the 6 small scars and realize it was not. Best of luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas, RALP now 4 days away

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I believe so. I see it referred to as the prostate fossa, or bed: the depression or area where the prostate was. Of course if other precise areas are revealed on imaging, those can be targeted too, in theory. The prostate fossa may in fact have residual prostate tissue missed in the RP and the areas at positive margins with other structures may be targeted. This is just what I've surmised from reading. Other brothers who have gotten SRT can be more precise. From what I have read, you can never be sure about Lymph Nodes (LN), unless they are all sampled, and a sample is just that? And any positive margins are red flags for the bed, although, in my case the sampling of the Periprostatic tissue showed no cancer. But my RO wants to be aggressive, for reasons Djintonic points out, plus, the fact that 3 of 7 LN's were positive and wants to go higher than normal, to the periaortic LN's, to be sure everything is hit. So, one has to weigh aggressiveness and possible toxic affects with missing the millions of cancer cells that can be in one cubic millimeter of space, that won't necessarily show up on even the Axumin PET scan, and become harder to kill once they mutate and are attempted to fry later! With today's advanced RT equipment and, in my case, the proposed use of Cone-Beam CT, IMRT, and the aggressiveness of my cancer, I agree with my RO (who was once head of the MO RO Association & on the board of the US Association), to throw everything at it. Bottom line, however, for each of us, you have to decide, on your own with recommendations, of course, what procedure is best for you!

Posts.Title: Seminal vesicles spread

Posts.Content: Jeff, I don't see anything about lymph nodes. Were any examined? 3 of 7 of mine sampled were cancerous, thus, the RT, I start next month will also be aimed at the numerous nodes, in case something is lurking and not killed by the Lupron. The dosage is only 45 gys vs. 65 for the Prostate bed. Like several of us I am having the Trifecta to cover all of the bases. My RO is using cone beam ct imaging to even further narrow the field to better target exactly where the radiation is going. He claims he has seen a reduction of 5% in SE's with this approach, already. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Day 11, post RALP with pathologic data

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by redbelly7 Let this life continue on and waiting on the last day of Lupron. Kinda wondering if there will be any sex life after all of this, but I have kind of made my peace w/ it. redbelly, how long have you been on Lupron and what other SE's did you have? What levels of RT did you have? As for sex life, at my age, don't see it as a big deal, even though before surgery, I had no ED whatsoever and almost felt oversexed. Now that the lust has been tempered, it is amazing to realize how much time was wasted thinking about and being so distracted (mentally) by the shapely ladies, including my wife. Heck you can't watch much TV, movies, commercials without the distraction. At the church I used to go to, women were coming in with cleavage, even. Now I can give my wife a shoulder or back rub and not immediately want to jump her, so to speak! Different strokes for different folks; no pun intended! Unfortunately, we men with normal testosterone levels are not much different than dogs when it comes to this issue. Of course, the good Lord made us that way to keep the human race from dying off, so it has it's time and place, especially for the younger pups.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I was reviewing the path report from my positive biopsy, which was done by LabCorp at Research Triangle Park, NC, where they have large facilities. I noticed, after the pathologist's name, the comment "This case was reviewed at the daily intradepartmental conference." This has me wondering does this or do most path labs review all cases, just the ones with bad news, the hard-to-call ones? Does anyone have a similar comment on their path report? My G scores were so dismal that I didn't even discuss getting a 2nd path opinion with my doc. But some reports (e.g. 4+3 vs 3+4) can obviously be critical--how many of you sought a 2nd opinion? How many expert eyes are looking at the average biopsy (or post-RP) slides? Djin Djin, Yes, mine was done by Dianon Systems and it states, "This case was reviewed at the daily intradepartmental conference." Our Uro said Dianon is one of the largest systems analyzing biopsies.

Posts.Title: Are path reports usually reviewed before release?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by redbelly7 Let this life continue on and waiting on the last day of Lupron. Kinda wondering if there will be any sex life after all of this, but I have kind of made my peace w/ it. redbelly, how long have you been on Lupron and what other SE's did you have? What levels of RT did you have? As for sex life, at my age, don't see it as a big deal, even though before surgery, I had no ED whatsoever and almost felt oversexed. Now that the lust has been tempered, it is amazing to realize how much time was wasted thinking about and being so distracted (mentally) by the shapely ladies, including my wife. Heck you can't watch much TV, movies, commercials without the distraction. At the church I used to go to, women were coming in with cleavage, even. Now I can give my wife a shoulder or back rub and not immediately want to jump her, so to speak! Different strokes for different folks; no pun intended! Unfortunately, we men with normal testosterone levels are not much different than dogs when it comes to this issue. Of course, the good Lord made us that way to keep the human race from dying off, so it has it's time and place, especially for the younger pups.

Posts.Title: how long after radiation can I go back to roughage?

Posts.Content: Here is my experience on 1/31/18. I had a RALP, 11/15/17, so my experience may be different. I was not suppose to drive, for 24 hrs., because of the Propofol. Had Fiducials placed (4 gold markers), 2/1/18. Had to do a low fiber/residue diet, 2 day before. Also, had to take a laxative 6 pm night before and restrict food/water intake at midnight. Also, had to do 2 fleet enemas 1 hr. before leaving. Was given Propofol and inserted an ultrasound device, in the rectum for viewing the placement, and a catheter (smaller in dia. than the foley we had after surgery) into the bladder. Fortunately, this was all done while I was in dreamland and didn't feel a thing! 2 markers were put even with the L4 Vertebrate (where Prostate was) and the remaining 2 in the Prostate bed. I am not limited to doing anything and return for my simulation on 2/6/18 and then RT approximately 2 weeks later.

Posts.Content: Here is my RO, who specializes in Cyberknife. I am using him for Adjuvant RT. Board-certified in radiation oncology, John Bedwinek, M.D., is a graduate of Columbia University and completed his fellowship at the prestigious University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center. Dr. Bedwinek has more than 30 years of experience in patient care with a special interest in breast cancer, prostate cancer and CyberKnife treatment. He has more than 50 publications, both in peer reviewed journals and book chapters. He has been on America’s Best Doctors list every year since its inception in 1997. Dr. Bedwinek was also named by Good Housekeeping magazine as one of “America’s Top Breast Cancer Doctors.” He has been awarded fellowships in the American College of Radiology, the College of Radiation Oncology and the American Society of Radiology and Oncology. http://www.stlouiscyberknife.com/john-bedwinek/ http://www.stlouiscyberknife.com/about

Posts.Title: CyberKnife

Posts.Content: Cog, You are on the other side. Hopefully, your scrotum does not swell up and turn black and blue, like mine did, which is not uncommon. Makes it harder to walk. Your abdomen will be swollen for some time and you will look like you have been in a knife fight! Every day it gets better and you start to feel more normal. Hang in there!
